list.li: Select a Planetary Gearbox from the major gearbox manufacturers
Select a Servomotor from the major manufactures
Plot the Application Load Torque-Speed curve, in four quadrants
Plot the Gearbox Load Torque-Speed curve, in four quadrants

body.para: Note: Use this tool with one degree-of-freedom kinematic-chains. Email PSMotion if the kinematic-chain has two or more degrees-of-freedom, each with a servomotor.

para.text: How to open the Kinetostatic-Torque and Speed dialog
You must be able to see the
Move the Power Source to the correct joint

list.style: font-family:'Segoe UI Semibold'; font-size:11pt; font-weight:bold; color:#000000;
font-family:'Segoe UI Semibold'; font-size:11pt; font-weight:bold; color:#000000;

td.para: See How to open a dialog
Before you select a Gearbox or Servomotor, the plot is Torque vs Speed of the Application Load, in four-quadrants.
The is the load that the Servomotor and Gearbox must drive. It does NOT include the load to drive the inertia and friction of the Gearbox and Servomotor.

para.text: When inertia is the dominant load,
we characterize the load for you as:

td.para: + Torque, + Speed - when accelerating the load in the positive direction
– Torque, + Speed - when decelerating the load in the positive direction
– Torque, – Speed - when decelerating the load in the negative direction
+ Torque, - Speed - when decelerating the load in the negative direction
The Auto-Filter check-box is at the top and right of the dialog.
When Auto-Filter is off, you can select from 1000s of Gearboxes.
We recommend that you enable the Auto-Filter. When Auto-Filer is enabled, the Gearboxes presented are limited to those that have a:

list.li: Lower-Torque Capacity that is greater than the Torque required to move the Application Load.
Upper-Torque Capacity that is determined by the Range-Factor.

td.para: The Range-Factor is at the top of the dialog.
Thus, the capacity of the Gearboxes that are listed for you are summarized by:
Lower Gearbox Torque Capacity = Equivalent Application (Load) Torque (21.495 N.m.)
Upper Gearbox Torque Capacity = Range Factor × Equivalent Application (Load) Torque (1.3 × 21.495 = 27.944 N.m.)
There are four Gearbox manufacturers from which you can choose: APEX, Neugart, Vogel, and Wittenstein
Note: If you need us to list a different Gearbox Manufacturer, then please email us.

image.caption: Gearbox manufacturer and Gearbox model part numbers

td.para: When you select a Gearbox Manufacturer, and Auto-Filter is ON, and you have entered a Range-Factor, the list of Gearboxes is limited to those whose capacity can satisfy these in-equalities:
The Selected the Gearbox Model Part Number
Each manufacturer has a different Model Part-Number format.

After you select a Gearbox model, its Gearbox Parameters Summary Sheet show. This form is read-only.
On the left of the sheet, there should be four(4) × to indicate that the Gearbox has the capacity to drive the Application Load and satisfies the 4 requirements.
Notes: Speed parameters in brackets ( ) are referred to the output-shaft. They are calculated from the Gear-Ratio of the Gearbox.

list.li: Backlash
Stiffness
Efficiency
Shaft Diameter - the input-shaft diameter, which is not in the list until you select a Servomotor.
Inertia - referred to the input, which is not in the list until you select a Servomotor.

td.para: Note: Not all Gearbox manufacturers provide all of these parameters.

toggle.caption: Gearbox Output Torque vs Speed plot

image.caption: Torque-Speed plot at Output of Gearbox.

td.para: When you select a Gearbox, the Torque (N.m.) vs Speed (RPM) plot changes to indicate whether the Gearbox has the capacity to drive the Application Load.

list.li: Green : Torque AND Speed of the Load ≤ Rated Gearbox Capacity
Amber : Torque OR Speed of the Load ≥ Rated Gearbox Capacity ≤ Maximum Gearbox Capacity
Red : Torque OR Speed of the Load ≥ Maximum Gearbox Capacity

image.caption: Torque-Speed at Gearbox at Output with Gearbox Limits

td.para: The Show Gearbox Limits check-list box is located above the Gearbox selection box.
The axes are auto-scaled to the Maximum Torque and Speed, at the output of the Gearbox.

para.text: The axes are auto-scaled to the Maximum Torque and Speed Capacity, referred to the output of the Gearbox.

td.para: This helps you compare the Torque and Speed Capacity of the Gearbox with the Application Load.
The Limits of Torque and Speed are shown as boxes.
Before you select a servomotor, the limit boxes and their color codes indicate the:

list.li: Dark Blue : Maximum Torque and Speed capacity of the Gearbox
Light-Blue : Rated (or Nominal) Torque and Speed capacity of the Gearbox
Light-Brown : Equivalent Torque and Speed of the Application Load

td.para: There are many Servomotor manufacturers from which to select.
When you select a Servomotor Manufacturer, we find for you those Servo-motors that have the Torque and Speed Capacity required by the Application Load.

image.caption: Servo-motor manufacturers and Servo-motor part numbers

td.para: Note: If you need us to list a different Servomotor Manufacturer, then please email us.

para.text: is limited to those whose capacity can satisfy these in-equalities:

td.para: Each manufacturer has a different model format.

font-family:'Segoe UI Semibold'; font-size:9pt; font-weight:bold; vertical-align:sub;

td.para: The Servomotor Shaft Diameter, D, must fit directly into the Gearbox, d1.
Note: Precision Planetary Gearboxes can accept a range of shaft diameters at their input. The Gearbox inertia, which is referred to its input, is different for each shaft diameter.

td.para: When you select a servomotor model, its Servomotor Parameters Summary Sheet show. This form is read-only.
To the left of the sheet, there should be five(5) × to indicate that the Servomotor has the capacity to drive the Application Load and also satisfies those 5 × requirements.
Peak Servomotor Torque ≥ Maximum Application (Load) ÷ i
Rated Servomotor Torque ≥ Equivalent Application (Load) Torque ÷ i
Max Servomotor Speed ≥ Maximum Application (Load) Speed × i
Continuous Servomotor Speed ≥ Equivalent Application (Load) Speed × i

list.li: Vdc - Bus Voltage for Drive
Jm - Servomotor Inertia
D - Servomotor shaft diameter.

td.para: When you select a Servomotor, colors of the dots for the Torque (N.m.) vs Speed (RPM) plot changes to indicate whether the Servomotor has the Capacity to drive the Application Load or not.

list.li: Green : Torque AND Speed of the Load ≤ Rated Servomotor Capacity
Amber : Torque OR Speed of the Load ≥ Rated Servomotor Capacity ≤ Maximum Servomotor Capacity
Red : Torque OR Speed of the Load ≥ Maximum Servomotor Capacity

td.para: The Show Motor Limits check-list box is located above the Motor selection box.
The axes are auto-scaled to the Maximum Torque and Speed, at the Servomotor Drive Shaft.

para.text: The axes are auto-scaled to the Maximum Torque and Speed Capacity of the Selected Servomotor

td.para: This helps you compare the Torque and Speed Capacity of the Servomotor with the Application Load referred to its input-shaft.
The Limits of Torque and Speed are shown as boxes.

list.li: Purple : Maximum Torque and Speed capacity of the Servomotor
Pink : Rated (or Nominal) Torque and Speed capacity of the Servomotor
Light-Brown : Equivalent Torque and Speed of the Application Load

toggle.caption: Why the Motor Torque is different to the Mechanism Torque

para.text: The Torque we calculate for you when you

is the torque to move the mechanism only. This is the Application Torque. The Application Torque does not include the Torque to move the motor and gearbox. It is necessary to add the Torque to accelerate the motor and the gearbox to the Torque in the graphics-area.
Clearly, the Torque to move a motor depends on the inertia of the motor and gearbox and the gearbox ratio.
The higher the gear ratio, the less Application Torque the motor 'sees'. But the motor must run faster and accelerate more. This influences the overall power, and the system efficiency.

toggle.caption: More on Torque vs Speed Curves

para.text: The performance characteristics of a brushless servo motor (motor/drive combination) are described by a torque/speed operating envelope.
As shown below, the colored areas of the curve identify the Exceeded Duty, Continuous Duty, and Intermittent Duty working areas of the system.

td.para: To maximum speed and/or the maximum torque, of the gearbox and/or Servomotor must be exceeded. Usually, to make sure this cannot happen, there is a Current (amps) Limit on the Power Drive.

The continuous duty zone is bounded by the maximum continuous stall torque up to the intersection with the intermittent duty line. The continuous torque line is set by either the motor’s maximum rated temperature, or the drive's rated continuous current output, whichever is less.
The system maximum continuous or 'voltage line' is set by the voltage rating of the drives, the line voltage supplied, and the motor winding.
The system can operate on a continuous basis anywhere within this area, assuming the ambient temperature is 40°C or less.

The intermittent duty zone is bordered by the peak-stall torque and the system voltage line. The peak torque line is set by either the drives’ peak current rating, which the drive can give for a limited time, or the maximum rated peak current for the motor, whichever is less. Higher torque levels may be achievable at higher power levels.

image.caption: Typical Torque / Speed Duty Capability of a Brushless Servomotor.

para.text: The Peak Torque the Motor and Gearbox at Stall Speed
The Continuous Torque the Motor and Gearbox can give Continuously at Stall Speed.
Maximum possible speed of the Motor and Gearbox. Not attainable when the voltage is limited by the drive.

td.para: Knee Speed: (ωK ) The Speed at 'knee' in peak envelope that is the intersection of the Peak Torque with the Voltage Torque/Speed Limit Line.

para.text: The Continuous Torque at the Speed of the Rated Power.
The Rated Speed or Speed at Rated Power. The motor can operate at this speed with the supply voltage.

toggle.caption: How we calculate the Motor Torque and Motor Speed

td.para: The Reflected Inertia at the Motor shaft can be constant or it can continuously change in a machine-cycle.
With Constant Inertia Mechanical Systems, it is easy to calculate Inertia Torque.
With mechanisms, the Torque is dependent on reflected inertia that is a function of Acceleration, Velocity, and Position.
PSMotion has developed algorithms to calculate these, which give a true indication of the reflected inertia at a motor shaft for even the most complex mechanisms.
The equations below, are calculated at every instant in a machine-cycle.
Usually, you aim to make the Reflected Load Inertia = (Motor + Gearbox) Inertia.
However, when the Load Inertia is not constant, it is more difficult to select the Motor and Gearbox.
TL = Load referred to Motor Shaft
TVD = Viscous 'Drag' Torque. It is always opposite to the direction of motion
TMD = Torque derived by your model at the Motor Shaft ( f{PL , ωL, αL } )
